en.value: Giving and understanding health advice - Imperative, Making suggestions
It's never fun when you're feeling unwell. Let's learn some expressions to use when giving and receiving advice about our health.
Are you eating well and getting enough vitamins?
You should avoid dairy for a week.
Get plenty of rest. You're probably exhausted.
There are different words we can use with "to get rest". We can use "some", "plenty of" or "enough" rest.
You'll feel better if you get some rest.
Make sure you get plenty of rest.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Are you eating well and getting enough vitamins?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
You should avoid dairy for a week.
Saying "to keep away from something" is another way of saying "to avoid something". We can use either a noun or an "- ing" verb after these.
Nico is on a diet. He should keep away from sugar.
This is opposite in meaning to "to avoid".
"To avoid" and "to keep away from" are similar in meaning.
Max has stomach problems. What should he avoid doing?
He should keep away from red meat.
He should keep away from dairy products.
He should keep away from alcohol.
Sleep will help you get better.
If you've been feeling unwell for a long time and nothing really helps, you'd better see a doctor.
I think you should see a doctor.
Why don't you make an appointment to see a doctor?
I had a check up this morning at the doctor's.
I think you should see a doctor.
Why don't you make an appointment to see a doctor?
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
I had a checkup this morning at the doctor's.
When was the last time you [k]had a checkup[/k]?
The doctor gave me a prescription.
She gave the patient a prescription.
She advised the patient to see another doctor.
Don't forget to take your medicine.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Exhausted! I didn't sleep again last night.
Oh no. Get [k]plenty of rest[/k] today. Are you eating well?
I think I ate too much meat yesterday evening.
I see. You should avoid eating heavy food before bed.
You're right. I need to try to [k]keep away from[/k] meat for a few days.
Good idea. Maybe you should [k]see a doctor[/k], too. When was your last checkup?
I can't remember. Ages ago. I'll [k]make an appointment[/k].
Good. He might give you a [k]prescription[/k] for some sleeping pills.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
You should [k]a[/k][k]v[/k][k]o[/k][k]i[/k][k]d[/k] eating heavy food before bed.
Select the words that also mean "to avoid something".
take medicine have a check up make appointment [h]keep[/h] [h]away[/h] [h]from[/h]
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Complete the sentence: "Sleep will ... you get better".
The doctor has given you a prescription. You should ...
You should have a medical [k]c[/k][k]h[/k][k]e[/k][k]c[/k][k]k[/k][k]u[/k][k]p[/k] every year.
Why don't you make an [k]appointment[/k] to see the dentist?
Fill in the gap using the image.
Imagine your friend's been feeling unwell for a while. Give him / her some advice.
You should get plenty of ... Are you eating ... ? You should avoid ... Why don't you see ... ?
There are many occasions when we tell someone to do something, and we can do so in many different ways. Here we'll learn how to do it using imperatives. Have a look at the examples below.
We can tell somebody to do something using an imperative.
We use imperatives to give orders, commands, instructions, advice and warnings, as well as to make requests by adding "please". To form an imperative, we simply use the base form of the verb.
There's a car coming, watch out!
Complete the sentence with an imperative.
Please give up your seat for elderly people.
Select the sentence that offers advice.

We try and use the imperative carefully in English, as it is a very direct form. We can use words such as "just" or "please" to make an imperative sound less direct. Have a look at the examples below.
Which word would make the sentence you hear sound less direct?
We often come across imperatives in instruction manuals and recipes, as they are an easy way of giving clear instructions. Look at the examples below.
Press and hold the power button for 5 seconds.
Select the sentence we might find in an instruction manual.
Remove the screws from the packaging.
We are removing the screws from the packaging.
We removed the screws from the packaging.
Complete the recipe with the imperative.
[k]Fry[/k] the aubergine in lots of oil.
Select the sentence that uses the imperative politely.

To form a negative imperative, we add "do" + "not" before the verb. The full form "do not", is more formal and it makes the instruction sound stricter or more powerful. In speaking, we usually say "don’t".
Find the mistake in the sentence below. Select the incorrect word.
Fill the gap to form a more informal negative instruction.
If we want to include ourselves in the imperative statement, rather than just giving an order to another person, we use "let's" before the verb.
Let's not go to that restaurant again.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
What is Julie suggesting they do?
Complete the sentence using an imperative "Let's ... out for dinner tonight".
We use the imperative to give orders, instructions and advice, and to make requests. Imperative forms can sound quite direct, so we can add "please" to sound more polite.
We use the base form of the verb.
We add "don't" before the verb to make it negative.
We add "let's" before the verb to include ourselves.
Complete the sentence to tell people to be quiet.
Type a word to make this command more polite.
[k]Don't start|Do not start[/k] without the right tools.
Complete the sentence to say you need to heat the water up.
[k]Don't open the window|Do not open the window[/k].
Complete the sentence to suggest having dinner.
You're in the park. There's a sign asking you not to sit on the grass.
[k]Please do not|Please don't|Do not|Don't[/k] sit on the grass.
Nick and Laura discuss how they can lead a healthier life.
Are you okay? You look tired.
Yeah, I have not been feeling well recently. I'm pretty run down. Work has been very stressful and I don't have any time for myself.
Oh no. Maybe [k]you should[/k] take some time off. Or [k]have you[/k] thought about working fewer hours?
I can't, we have so many new people at work and I need to train them and do my own job at the same time.
Hm, that sounds exhausting. [k]Why don't[/k] you speak to your manager?
I have, she's trying to help with my workload.
That's a good start! Also, have [k]you tried[/k] yoga or running? It helps me relax.
That's a great idea, thanks Laura!
We often make suggestions in all kinds of everyday conversations. So let's take a look at some phrases that will be helpful when suggesting something to a friend.
Have you thought about changing your diet?
Why don't you cut back on caffeine?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Have you thought about quitting smoking?
Have you tried talking to your manager about it?
Have you tried talking to your manager about it?
This means the speaker already talked to her manager.
Have you thought about using food supplements?
Why don't you cut back on sugar?
How might we ask if someone has already considered something?
How might we check whether a friend has already done what you're about to suggest?
What might we say when we want to make a concrete suggestion?
What else can we say to make a suggestion?
[k]Why don't you[/k] cut back on sugar?
